Riecht nicht schlecht nach Hopfen fur ein Lager (ist aber Hopfengestopft), könnte dafür aber auch kräftiger riechen. Im Geschmack recht kräftig für ein Lager und bitter, aber nicht ausgeprägt kräftig. Ins Summe ganz ok.
Draft beer at OHSO at Brighton Beach, decent lager, very straight forward and a bit boring, floral, smells nice but no aftertaste to speak of.

Sat in ONeils, Oxford, Friday 2nd June 2017, Slowdive Gig to attend later at O2 Academy  Not really my thing and also not really sure why on earth I ordered a pint, I came here because I had a 40% off voucher plus on top of that I noted my bank was doing 20% cashback and heard that the food was fine. Beer is cool, refreshing, sweet and dull, but I was thirsty and so it sort of worked. Ok. I am already sick of the playlist, I know its an ONeils but really just playing Irish tracks? Ok were branching out the Undertones now sees us move across the border.  A5 A4 T5 P3 Ov11 2.8

Golden color, medium carbonation. Grassy and malty aroma, not too strong. Pretty straightforward flavor, malty, bready, a bit sweet, a bit hoppy in the finish, which expresses itself as a bit of tartness and touch of bitterness. From the name, I expected it to have more of a hop presence. Not great, not bad. Just there.
Great tasting larger that has a mixture of fruit and hop taste about it. I find it much better from bottle rather than draft.
No poprosze fajny lager. Nie lubie lagerow ale tego lubie.Polecam Bo to fajne piwko.

Draught in the Wetherspoons in Hertford. Nice appearance. Well balanced taste that quickly dissipates to nothing. Unsophisticated thereafter - not a lot to say about it, negative or positive. Better than your cheap pub usual suspects but not one to seek out.

Seriously boring. It is so bland I wouldn’t be surprised to find out it was being packaged and sold as a supermarket own- brand lager. Despite the presence of the word "hop" in the title, it’s bland and largely flavorless, with no hop aroma at all.
Hop House = utter shithaus having paid £5 for probably the worst tasting lager in the world! Utter drivvel

It’s a good lager. More taste than you would usually find and it’s refreshing, not being overly
fizzy either. Can’t think of too many better of the top of my head
Golden-amber, thick head. Light caramel nose with a touch of green apple. Mild bitterness, and a clash of green apple and caramel. Hops, huh?

Tap at the Commodore in Cobh, Ireland. Pours golden amber with a white head. Aroma seems floral and lightly spicy. Med body. Flavor is somewhat bready, but there’s some floral and grass or spice or both. Seems more ale than lager. What’s the test for that? Me liking it. :) Not to be sought, but not to be avoided.

33cl from a rough Cambridge night shop. Fizzy gold. Aroma of frosties cereals with a touch of lemon air freshener. Unpleasantly thin cereal base and lemongrassy notes interfering with what already drinks like a diluted Märzen with an identity crisis. The perfect bland taste of utopia, a globalised nowhere concocted of too little of anything all at once.
650ml bottle. Clear golden with a foamy white head. Grassy, citrus aroma, taste is crisp, refreshing, decent lager
Pint from keg at The Grenadier. Low-Medium carbonated lager, good start but finishing is not very rewarding, with a slight metallic taste at the end

Pours amber with a slightly off white head. Nose is sour and bit of biscuit malt, citrus and a hint of tinned peach. Fairly thin in the mouth , sour margerine taste, bit of citrus and the smallest whiff of hops. It’s not the worst lager I’v ever had but im really struggling to like this, it’s quite nasty in the aftertaste. Damn I bought a 4 pack.
Keg half pint at Malone’s Irish Bar, Aberdeen. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma of diacetyl / butterscotch. Slightly sweet flavour, loads of diacetyl, Too moderate hops. Won’t buy again.
Pours a clear and carbonated gold with white head. A grainy and light citrus and pine aroma. A grainy taste with some citrus, pine and malts. A little getting dry grain and malty aftertaste.

Tap at O’Donoghue’s Bar, Dublin. Poured a crystal clear light amber with a frothy white head and plenty of bubbles. The aroma is malt, light tropical fruit. The flavour is moderate bitter light sweet with a light, crisp, grainy mineral, fruity hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.
Draught. Creamy White good mostly deminishing head. Dark yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter herbal flavor. Average light bitter finish. Watery palate.

On tap at Real Sports. ‎Pours a clear golden colour with average-sized white head with decent retention. Aroma is ‎quite grassy with some graininess. Flavour has lots of dry grassiness with a bit of graininess. Average body. Ok.

Off white frothy head stayed on a translucent, slightly effervescent, copper coloured body.
Sweet, floral aroma - typically lager style.
Medium bodied, airy on the palate, feels soft. Prickly on the back. 
Malt, sweet, floral, caramel & watery aft.

Live Rating of a 660 ml bottle from Tesco served cold in a Moretti pint chalice. Dark gold with a dense white head fading to a skim. Honey and lemon aroma. Hints of both in the flavour, but lacking commitment. Also more heavy than zingy on the palate. Not irredeemably awful, just a bit "meh"... and I had hopes. Actually, It’s getting up to "superior holiday brew" standard as it warms. Might even buy again.

Bottle. Dark golden. Regular head with nice lacing. Aroma of floral and fruity hops. Taste is fruity (apricots, citrus fruits), grainy, kind of sweet and malty. It’s missing some bitterness. Medium carbonation. Creamy. There’s something in the aftertaste which I don’t like but I can’t put my finger on it...Alright but I don’t really see myself buying this ever again.

March 2016. Bottle from local offie. Dark gold with an evanescent tuft of head. Aroma of dishwater, those bits of vegetable that get stuck in the plughole, lemon icing. Wheaty lemon citrus character with a green herbal coriandered note leaning towards Belgium. Actually quite refreshing.

0.33l bottle. Malty aroma, hopy notes, light yeasty notes. Clear golden color, white head. Malty taste, hopy notes, medium bitter. Medium body, oily texture, average cabonation and bitter finish. Good.
330ml bottle. Strange orange colour. Corn grain aroma. Dry grain vanilla flavour. Smooth, perfumey aftertaste. Not a typical lager.

Aroma is light sweet grains, pale earthiness and citrus. Taste is honey, caramel, citrus, apricot, and clove. Pretty light body overall and i would consider this sessionable. Appearance is a clear gold with a thin pearl head that retains fairly well.

Draught @ The Dove Street Inn, Ipswich. Pours light golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of light malt, light buttery, little grass. Flavor is light sweet, malt, hint of butter, little fruit, little grass. Thin body, average carbonation. 150217

Tap @ The Dove Street Inn, Ipswich. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, light buttery and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 150217
Tap @ Dove Street, Ipswich. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grass, fruits and hops. Sweet finish.

Pint on tap at The Garrick Bar, Belfast. Clear golden with a dense, lasting, white head. Slightly fruity and hoppy, but mostly the mild grainy aroma. Moderate to medium sweet with mild grainy flavours and a rather light bitterness. Close to the usual industrial pale lager, far from impressive, but drinkable.
Bottle at home. Leaps better than harp lager but nothing out of the ordinary. Avoids tinny flavour which is nice.
Smells funky, looks good, feels ok, tastes as described (hopped). Not for me but tolerable.
This is not as bad as I expected. Not good either but is a well made drinkable lager.

Actually a really nice refreshing lager with notable hops coming through, doesnt taste like you normal mass produced lagers this beer a tually is quite enjoyable, bottle is great but if you find it on draught then even better.
Didn’t enjoy this on tap, but received some bottles and I must admit that it’s grown on me. Very hoppy, fresh and crispy

This was honestly the best beer I’ve ever drank. I tried it in O’Connell’s Bar in Dublin, a great taste with a variety in flavours that come together at the back of your tongue. Pure gold, that wat it is. It’s not bitter, nor sweet, it’s a well-balanced and a refreshing beer.
Bottle - pours gold with a small head. Aroma is cereal malt with a bit if fruity hop. Taste is moderately fruity up front with a mild dry finish.

Draft at Four Horsemen, Bournemouth. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma of fruity hops, citrus and light malt. Flavour is light sweet and light to moderate bitter. Light bodied with light carbonation. Quite enjoyed it.

Keg (Three Wise Monkeys, Colchester)

Not a pale lager really, has some colour to it. Sweet pale malt aroma. A bit harsh in the mouth, some popcorny diacety. Very dry and bitter finish. Messy and harsh.

Bottle: Deep golden, clear, small, lasting white head; mild malty nose with a slight bready/toasty touch and a delicate citrussy background; mild to moderate bitter-sweet flavour, unfortunately very light bodied, almost watery; lingering malty and lemony finish. Not bad, just way too thin...

33cl bottle thanks to Antonio. It pours a clean pale golden color with a medium creamy white head. Aroma is grainy and medium sweet and starchy. taste is also sweet and starchy with grains and corn flakes. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Overall, unexciting macro lager

Tried this in Dublin, its one of Guinness’s (Diageo’s) offerings. Quite bitter, almost acrid at the back of the tongue. If you’ve every tried baiju in China, this is reminiscent. Strong aroma of tomcat’s urine. Not nice, but at least it has a flavour, unlike Guinness draft.
When an IPA is too hoppy, this may be just the ticket - an excellent, well-balanced lager!
A nice beer on a cold night. Surprised by low ratings. It’s beer!!!!!!!!!!!!!

33cl bottle.
Thick creamy white head. Clear golden pour. Lacks bitterness. Ok.
Aroma 4. Appearance 3. Taste 6. Palate 3. Overall 10. Not so hoppy but a good lager.

bottle from pip. got me a wee pressie for helping her through her job interviews and a stressful couple of weeks. what a gal. pours deep golden, medium head. peachy citrus aroma. tastes of honey, zesty fruits, hops. quite balanced. drunk with pizza and telly, what friday nights were made for

Bottle,from memory. A nice attempt at a lager with a twist, i think expectations are raised abit too much calling this ’hop house’. Taste is predominantly biscuity malt with clean light flowery hops, but by no means a ’hoppy’ beer A decent lager, no mistake, but it ends up being a poor-mans ale
330ml bottle from Asda. Pours yellow with a short lived foamy white head. Aromas are malty and floral hops. Sweet, a little peppery. Pleasant among pale lagers.
Bottle. Pours golden. Aroma of light malts and tobacco. Quite floral. Light sweet taste. Decent enough pale lager.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours golden, with a small white head. Aromas sweet floral and malty. Mild body, but with a characteristic floral hoppiness to it, not bitter, fairly dry, the bitterness appears only in the finish and is very mellow.

Keg. Poured a golden amber with a small but lasting white head. Plenty of pale malt characters supplemented by a good degree of grassy, pithy hops. Not too much in the way of grain. Light to medium body, medium carbonation and a soft to moderate length and intensity hop bitterness to finish.
Clear golden appearance. Aroma and flavour have a touch of toasted malts. Slightly more flavoursome than other macro lagers.
Keg at ox184. Pours golden, nose is toffee, floral, grassy, taste is sweet, grainy, cereal.

Bottle. Pours medium light amber and gently opaque with a thin white foam subsiding average. Scent is light floral notes and medium light hop character. Taste is medium floral notes and light caramel notes. Light resin. Finish is a little skunky and a bit like honey wax. Interesting. Surprisingly very good.

Pours deep golden with a decent head. Malty aroma with fruits and a hint of hay. Taste is sweetish with fruits, bread and liquorice. Lively co2. Tasty brew despite a low ABV. More than just another lager. (500ml bottle, bb 10.05.17)

Looks: dirty golden with a thin white head, minimal lacing, high carbonation. Aroma: Apricot, peach, grassy hops, some floral notes. Taste: apricot, peach, hops, slightly bitter malty aftertaste. A nice alternative to the usual rubbish domestic lager the UK is "treated" to.
Bottle from Bargain Booze, Whitby. Golden coloured with a thin white head. It has a gentle grassy and toffee flavour followed by a smooth bitter-sweet finish. A little bland.

Bottle from B&M Bargains, Ashton Gate, Bristol. Deep gold in colour, with a tight, yet small, white head and moderate carbonation. Light aroma of sweetish, rich tea malts, hay and a touch of leafy hop. Flavour was also sweet, with cereal mlats, a hint of stone fruit and decent, bitter, finish. A solid lager.

4,1% ABV op het etiket. Helder goudblond bier met witte schuimkraag. Geur: groenten, mout, geen hop!. Smaak: moutzoet, granen, zonder enige bitterheid. Goede koolzuurprikkel. Flauwe pils. Waar is de hop?

Keg at the Hobgoblin, High Wycombe. Light bronzey-amber with a moderate white head and a light fizz. Caramel to the fore with light grassy hops and a moderate bitterness. Quite a full body for a lager, but slightly sticky as a result. Much better than I expected (not that my expectations were very high!) and strangely more like a summer cask bitter than a lager.
Bottle. Lightly sparkling amber body. Frothy white head without much retention. Nose is citrus, straw, hay, grass, Brett, fruit, tangerines. Bittersweet and tangy. Dry finish. Good.
Clear yellow, off-white lasting, lacing foam head. Nice crisp barlye aroma and bitter taste. Nice. (Belfast 201608)
Bottle a golden yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts water some citrus and hops flavor malts citrus water en hops
Somewhat sweet lager with a hint of corn and bread. Clean tasting, decent enough.

Bottle from Waitrose. Quite a dark amber colour. Hmm sweet quite peachy and a bit buttery. A bit thin, drinks easily. Occupies a kind of weird space which shouldn’t be weird somewhere between a pale summery bitter and a lager. For me could be cleaner and more bitter.
*On tap in Ireland. Smooth malty hints, sessionable, malty layer with some floral hints. Fresh, round with a nice Ale character aftertaste.

Bottle. It really is a perfectly respectable lager. No unpleasant ’batchy’ notes, finishes quite smoothly, has some decent bread-y and biscuity character. Hint of hops, okay malt character. Setting commercial interests aside, it’s a beer that makes you ask, ’why?". Ah well, a decent lager if need be.
Keg. Appearance is amber, clear, plenty of bubbles rising, a solid white head. Aroma of cereal, malt and slight spicy hints. Taste is malty, fairly full-bodied, hoppy crisp finish. Good lager.
Tap. Clear golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, hop, caramel and grass. Flavour is malt, caramel, hop, grass, medium sweet and a little bitter.

330ml bottle from Tesco. Pours clear amber, with little white head. Lightly carbonated with heavy grainy aroma. Taste is odd, slightly metallic with a very faint apple overtones. Finish is a little bit acidic. Wouldn’t go out of my way to have this again.
Draft at The Habit York. Pilsener pour. A: light hoppy exotic fruit (very light), some pilsener malts and citrus. T: follows aroma. Standard bitter lager finish.

330ml bottle at home on 22nd July 2016: poured slowly into a Duvel tulip. Looked good, a clear light amber body with a full, deep white crown on top. Grainy nose and grainy lead in the strange metallic taste. Oh dear, what has gone on here? Aroma is fine, took some strong Cheddar to bring the taste and flavours back in line and away from ’wet cardboard and metal plating’. Different but odd. The Brewers Project or whatever the ’gimmick’ is needs some tweaking.

Bottle. Golden colour typical of a lot of lagers. Head dissipates quickly. Fruity with mild hoppy notes on the nose. Fruity and hoppy taste, enough to be refreshing without being over powering or too metallic. Mild slightly grassy finish. Nice for a summers day. Would drink again. 

 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Bottle from local Waitrose. Pours a clear golden color with a light tan, loose head. The smell is mild fruit, toasted malt...not a lot going on. The taste is crisp and fruity, some toasted malt and a touch of brown sugar sweetness while ending dry. Light+ in body with fairly active, course carbonation. It’s just OK...

Pint on keg in Radisson Hotel, Galway. Clear amber lager with white head. Nose has a bit more going on in it than lager. Usual elements, slightly sweet grain, crisp dry lager yeast, straw, slight grass and something fruitier. Body is typically macro lager but taste has a bit of extra hop and fruit. Some decent grassiness in it too.

Bottle at the Golf Hotel in Ipswich. Pours golden, rather flat, uninspiring to look at. Aroma is ok, sweet, some hop evident, also marzipan. Medium sweetness, a tangy bitterness which wasn’t that nice. Thinnish body, weak, carbonation feels artificially forced despite it producing little as head. Finish is unpleasant too. Checked the BBE date thinking it may have expired but no. This is not good at all.
On tap at The Station, West Byfleet. 13/07/16. Sweet hazy aroma. Amber, with a good white head. Carbonation visible. Light and frothy body. Sour, chemically, with a sweet backtaste. OK.
Keg at kash... Big white head... Soft dry grass fruit nose.. Big zezty fruits.. Soft banana fruit.. Zesty juicy fruit

Butelka  klarowny zloty kolor. Piana biala dosc obfita szybko opadajaca. W smaku i zapachu lekkie chmiele trawa sloma mokry karton. Nie odrzuca. 

 MarcinG

On tap at killarny. Clear yellow colour medium white head. Nose is very faint basicly no nose at all. Taste is low hoppy citrrusses. Dry mouhfeel. Green vegtably-leavy notes in the aftertaste. Decent actually, far better than i expected.
Bottle from B&M; clear amber pour with a big frothy off white head, aroma has grass and light citrus, taste has pale malts, crisp citrus and mown grass.
Draft. A golden beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of straw and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw and malt, leading to a bitter finish.

Florally hops on nose. Dark lager colour. Head ok. Fizzy looker. Hops and floral dominate. Ok. Pricey for what it is though. Would have again. 3.3.17 Sessions on it tonight and nice. Grapefruit , peaches, apricot and orange on nose . Gotta be cold to keep away skunk.
On tap at hotel in Dublin.Nice gold body with big head. Nose is hoppy as well. Taste of hops, with spices and caramel. Well-balanced.

Drunk from 50cl bottle in Ireland. Enjoyable lager style beer.
 



 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Macro yellow pour. Some creamy malt on the nose. Barley upfront with some bitter aftertaste. Not bad but nothing too special. On tap @ The Lord Lucan, Lucan, Ireland.

30th May 2016
Bright clear gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light, fairly dry and has decent fine carbonation. Light malts, mildly bready and with a touch of light creamy sweetness. Very mild tangy citrus underneath, whisper of lemon. Light semi dry finish. An okay and fairly clean tasting lager and no amount of slick advertising will make it more than that.
Een iets hoppiger pils, fris, prima, maar niet echt speciaal. Straks een goede steak

Draught  Small white head, clear golden-copper beer. Corn flakes, toasted malts. If there are ’more’ hops, I wonder more than where? Sweetish, pale malts, partly toasted. Hops??? Medium carbonation, ultra light body. OhsweetJeasus!

Despite my cynicism it’s not bad. Not much aroma. Pours crystal clear gold with generous head, moderate carbonation. Mixture of sweetness and hops, a bit Helles like. Drinks well to the bottom of the pint. Compare to other big corporate lager rubbish this tastes like someone has out some effort in. A decent pint if other options are lacking.
Bottle from Tesco. Pours clear pale golden. Nose is grainy malts, green beans and corn, light hops. Taste is light citrus, malts, light citrus hops, clean. Decent lager.
Keg @ Dockyard, Manchester. Clear golden with a frothy head. Has a mild crisp maltiness with some rye involved.

330ml bottle. Clear golden colour with a small white head, fairly shortlived. Aroma is hoppy, citrus fruit, lemon/orange zest, peach. Taste also unusually hoppy for a lager, sweet fruit, pale malt. Heavy carbonation, a bit too much in my opinion, also has an almost sticky mouthfeel like cola.

Interesting lager though, I enjoyed it, not a bad effort from Guinness. I feel like it’s been created as a gateway beer to IPAs and similar.
330ml bottle from Tesco - Yellow and fizzy. A fairly average lager, no off-flavours but nothing special either, a fairly run-of-the-mill lager. Oh, and smells of popcorn.

The beer has quite a nice look. The look is typical for a lager. The color of the beer is a beautiful golden yellow. The beer is crystal clear. A lot of bibles are rising towards the too lovingly. The beer pours a nice amount of rough white foam. The bulk of the foam collapses quickly, but a nice drape of foam remains on top of the beer. The smell of the beer is delicious. The beer is very hoppy. The hop aroma is quite sweet and fruity. It’s rather unique. It isn’t really the smell of an IPA, it is more delicate. The smell is more refined. The strong bitterness of an IPA is not present; instead there is an aprons fruitiness. I smell some delicious citrus fruits, and some tropical fruits such as peach. The taste is slightly less rich. There is the same sweet and slightly sour and bitter hop flavor that was also present in the smell. The beer is quite unique in my eyes. I can’t think of a beer like this. It’s a blend between IPA and regular lager. The beer is in good balance. I love it. I can’t wait thill this beer is available in stores in the Netherlands.
330ml bottle from Waitrose. Pours clear amber with foamy head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Aroma distinctive with wheat, raisins, bread dough and mango. Sweet taste with a lingering wheatiness.

Got the hops, and the head lasts, not a lot to get excited about but easy drinking and fairly crisp.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is a decent lager. Robust color and flavor. It’s light but it had some body. Fairly well rounded.
330ml bottle. Aroma of tropical fruit. Clean lager taste, slightly fruity. Quite good.
Bottle, Wine Tavern, Leicester. Golden with a a large white head. Bready with grain and light lemon. Peppery with hints of peach. Quite sweet with a flat finish.
330ml bottle. Pours dark gold with a medium head. Aroma is peach yoghurt, corn and lemon. Taste has peach and corn. Light bitter finish. Pleasant lager.
On draught. Light hop aroma and flavour. Its got hops, but little else of distinction.

330ml bottle at home in Richmond as ’Hop House 13 Lager’, 5%, BB Aug 2016. Dark amber orange, hazy, the odd bubble, small foamy off-white head, dotted lacing. Aroma is cardboard, cooked cabbage, metallics. Body is light, a bit foamy, spritzy carbonation. Taste is sweet, soda, gummy sweets, popcorn. Pros: clean with a bit of biscuit and fruit. Cons: too sweet and fizzy. The overcarbonation really kills this beer, when it could be half decent. My girlfriend’s view: "watery and smells like bad breath".
Pours a blonde colour. Aroma and taste is quite hoppy. Reminds me of Brewdog This is lager. Guinness trying to get into the craft beer scene? Good but could have been better
Bottle. Golden pour with small fluffy white head. Light aroma of malts and cereal. Lovely refreshing taste with subtle hops. An easy drinking lager. Was expecting more hops.

April 2016 330ml brown bottle, filtered, from Waitrose. A craft lager from Guinness. Or, rather, the Guinness Brewers Project. It’s a soft lager with a focus on the malt rather than the hops. Not bad for the strength, but otherwise unremarkable. Drinkable, but unremarkable. [2.4]

March 2017  Two Brothers Southampton. Aroma of tinned ice. Few hops. Soft malt. Its a drinkable beer, but not interesting or tasty. [2.4]
Pours more golden than most lagers taste corn minerals syrup bottle at home from tesco

33cl bottle from Waitrose, Wokingham. A straw coloured pour with a tight white head; grassy aroma with a hint of caramel; the taste has more caramel which blends well with the grainy body; the finish is pleasantly bitter with lingering caramel. An interesting twist on the standard lager profile, and one I’d be happy to try again.

On tap at The Crosse Keys Gracechurch Street. Clear deep gold colour lasting white head. It’s an ok premium lager. No puke or newspaper or cabbage. Some light lemon presence. Some malt presence ok fizzy cold.

Decent lager, amber colour with white head, grain, tofee, floral and a touch of orange in the smell, fairly sweet but refreshingly crisp and bitter in taste. As far as lager goes this is pretty decent and I will drink again

Bottle. Clear golden beer with a large white head. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel, bread, herbs, hay and toffee. Flavor is malty with notes of caramel, bread, herbs, hay, herbs and toffee. Well balanced.

Aroma: grain and cereal malts, light floral hops. Appearance: clear gold, small, creamy, white head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: grain and bread malts again, fruity, light citrus. Overall: boring Lager, don’t get me wrong, perfectly quaffable on a hot day. Pint at Craft Beer Rising, Shoreditch.

Not bad, mild hoppy taste. A little bit fruity. I found it pleasant, but not outstanding. I bought it with a bit of trepidation, but I’m always prepared to give something a go (regardless of whether it’s Micro or Macro). I wouldn’t specifically seek it out, but I’d have no qualms about drinking it again. A decent average.
Beer with gold color, light body, a little bit bitter, soft carbonized, (bought a 50cl bottle in Drogheda supermarket).
Bottle from tesco, West Bromwich. Golden beer with medium head. Aroma of peach and malts. Taste is same with a little dry hop. Not bad.
Bottle. Pours a dark gold colour with a firm white head, aroma is light and floral, the taste is medium bitterness with a thin dry finish.
Copper with white head. Floral, malt and light citrus. Dry, fruity and sweet finish. Overall: lightly hopped.

Bottle, from Bargain Booze, Brigg. Deep gold, fluffy and sustained white head and good condition. Low grainy malt and a little honey sweetness in the nose, with traces of hop resin emerging, quite bitter and estery in the mouth with a background of chalky dryness developing, finish is briefly dry with traces of malt and a low lingering earthy hoppiness

Keg, half-pint, at Silk Mill Cider & Ale House. Stable white head, lacing rings down the glass. Clear amber coloured body. Half-dry smell of grass and pale malts. Smooth flavour od mild peaches and pale malts. Rounded fruity ending. easy to drink. Soft carbonated. Decent foodpairing (Derby 21.02.2016).

Kash, Chester
Really stands out in your local when offered only the mainstream standard lager selection, here is was against Brooklyn which never appealed. Big hops, citrus nose with a fruity flavour. 5% so is better value than a Stella or Estrella and more flavour than a Peroni.

Keg at The Cobblers, Leek. A clear golden colour with a fizzy white head. Aroma of cereal malt, some caramel, a little lemon and subtle grassy hops. 
Taste of cereal malt, some caramel, subtle banana, slight biscuit, maybe fruit and a hint of grassy hops. Light bodied and moderate carbonation. A dry, malty bitterness in the finish. Quite a dry but smooth lager with a better body than I thought it would have. Unmistakable Guinness characteristics to this. Ok.

Silly little bottle . In a pint tulip : Had this in the middle of a session of Americanized UK beers , so this unassuming lager was obviously overshadowed by those beerz ... I guess this was a good palate cleaner ...
Nothing too wrong with this - its flaws are it being too sweet and grainy for my tastes . A more bitter body would help the character . Still, not bad .
Pours dark golden with a medium white head. Pleasant hoppy lager with some citrus aroma and faint citrus flavour and just a little sweetness. Decent

Lovely deep golden colour steady tight creamy head. Aroma sweet and fruity. Taste biscuit malt, caramel and slight dry hoppy fruitiness that isn’t too over powering. Nice balance tasty and bit different yet still refreshing lager.
Guinness really shouldn’t bother. This is awful. Bland and left a bit of an unpleasant cereal after-taste. Didn’t finish it.
Fra fat på Silk Mill i Derby 21 Feb 16. Gylden. Lavt tett skum som daler sakte. Aroma av gress. Smaken syrlig. Mest mais. Blir tørr etter hvert. OK matøl.

Bottle. Golden with an unusual hop flavour that is quite fresh. Not a flavour I would normally associate with this brewer. Although not unpleasant the flavour has a slightly cardboard background. Weird.

Keg at The Market Tavern, Durham, £4.70/pint. 

I expected little from this - W.I. Porter aside I’ve found the Guinness Brewers project beers to be pretty underwhelming. I was pleasantly surprised. A pleasant, citrus-tinged hop aroma and a smooth pale malt backing make this, as far as I’m concerned, a lager that’s worth drinking.

Not very good at all dissapointing.
Only good thing is its fresh and crisp other than that dull
Origin: Tap. Vessel: Nonic. Supplier: The Slug & Lettuce (Bristol). Foamy but surprisingly hoppy.
An unspectacular but perfectly serviceable lager. There’s hop, some fruit, a bit of banana. It’s crisp and drinkable.

Bottle, deep gold with a thick off-white foam, nose has hints of peach and grain, plus a non-unpleasant sweetcorn note. Palate is strongly hop-flavoured, sweet malt underneath, not much bitterness. Reminiscent of a top-fermented then lagered beer. Interesting and pretty good, but lacking in depth and that "same again please" drinkability.
Bottled, 330ml at The George & Dragon, Chacombe, Northants. Pale gold with short lived head. Thin, quite sweet malty lager, there is a slightly stewed note, boiled cereal hints. Not great.
330ml bottle thanks to Ashton McCobb. Pours clear golden amber with a thick white head. Aromas of lemon peel, biscuit. Taste is sweet, unpleasantly astringent finish.

Bottle thanks to Gary.
Appearance - golden amber with a decent head.
Nose - lemon and biscuit.
Taste - malt and lemon. Butter.
Palate - light bodied and sweet yet still astringent.
Overall - not pleasing .
Bottle from Metro Wines, Leicester. Golden orange colour with a big white head. Fruity and slight formal aroma. Sweet grainy taste.

Keg at the Eagle, Cambridge. Dark gold, clear with a smallish white head. Pleasant aroma of hibiscus, citrus and hay. Taste is quite sweet - artificially so - with a jarring saccharin aftertaste. Long medicinal finish. Thin body, carbonated to high heaven. Reasonable but won’t become a favourite of mine anytime soon.

Golden color with a nice white head. Looks good. Malty, herbal, mild citric and mild fruity. A quite fresh and nice lager. Medium body and a fine carbonation. Ok balance.
[On tap at Angels Share Dublin Airport, Ireland]

On tap at Oval, Dublin. Pours clear golden with a small white head. Aroma is malty caramel with some grassy hops. Taste is moderate sweet fruity malts, with a light grassy hoppy finish. Moderate carbonated, more than moderate dull.

Bevuta al Waterloo pub di Dublino. Colpo di fortuna. Alla vista un bel giallo brillante, limpida, carbonata. Schiuma fine e compatta. Al naso i luppoli fanno il loro lavoro conferendo dolcezza, mista al malto. In bocca un giusto equilibrio fra corp e beva frutto dell’equilibrio fra l’uso del malto e dei luppoli. Poesia.

When in Ireland was given this as my free pint at the Guinness storehouse as told by the bartender that I would like it. I not only liked it I loved it!!! It was all I drank while in Ireland. It had an apricot taste and was easy going down. I’d like to thank that bartender because he for sure knew what I would like.
Draft pour at brazenhead. Orange with white head - tastes like bigfoots dick. Not having this soldier again

The reason I came here is to share my opinion as someone who isn’t very experienced in beers and ales. I don’t enjoy many mainstream beers and I’m not big on bitter flavours. When I tried this beer I knew I had found my pint. It’s very subtle and a lot smoother than the likes of harp or cars berg which you find every where. The aroma is very faint, a small amount of hops and if you look hard enough, notes of tropical fruit. It’s looks well, golden with an orange hue and a nice frothy head that lasts throughout. This isn’t by any means a big hitting ipa, but it’s a very approachable lager that will go down well with people who don’t enjoy craft beers. A personal favourite!

Not sure why there are so many negative comments about this. I have to agree with previous posting about beer snobs. This isn’t an ale - it’s a lager and as such it beats the competition (Bud, Carlsberg & Heineken) into a cocked hat. The Brewery Project should be commended for this offering.
